computer science#computing research repository#computer vision and pattern recognition#NMR: Neural Manifold Representation for Autonomous Driving#Unnikrishnan R. Nair
column4: Srikanth Vidapanakal#"Autonomous driving requires efficient reasoning about the Spatio-temporal

column1: nature of the semantics of the scene. Recent approaches have successfully
amalgamated the traditional modular architecture of an autonomous driving stack
comprising perception
column3: and planning in an end-to-end trainable

column1: system. Such a system calls for a shared latent space embedding with
interpretable intermediate trainable projected representation. One such
successfully deployed representation is the Bird's-Eye View(BEV) representation
of the scene in ego-frame. However
column2: a fundamental assumption for an undistorted

column1: BEV is the local coplanarity of the world around the ego-vehicle. This
assumption is highly restrictive
resulting distortions make path planning inefficient and incorrect. To overcome
this limitation
representation for the task of autonomous driving that learns to infer
semantics and predict way-points on a manifold over a finite horizon
on the ego-vehicle. We do this using an iterative attention mechanism applied
on a latent high dimensional embedding of surround monocular images and partial
ego-vehicle state. This representation helps generate motion and behavior plans
consistent with and cognizant of the surface geometry. We propose a sampling
algorithm based on edge-adaptive coverage loss of BEV occupancy grid and
associated guidance flow field to generate the surface manifold while incurring
minimal computational overhead. We aim to test the efficacy of our approach on
CARLA and SYNTHIA-SF."#

column2: BN is typically ignored in SR

column2: and then switch to using population statistics at the

column1: later training period. While we have successfully re-introduced BN into SR

with the modified BN. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our simple RepSR

better trade-off between performance and actual running time (throughput) than

computer science#computing research repository#computer vision and pattern recognition#Arbitrary Shape Text Detection via Boundary Transformer#Shi-Xue Zhang
column4: Xu-Cheng Yin#"Arbitrary shape text detection is a challenging task due to its complexity

column1: and variety
column5: and curve shapes. In this

column1: paper
column2: we propose an arbitrary shape text detector with a boundary transformer

column1: which can accurately and directly locate text boundaries without any

field) for generating coarse boundary proposals meanwhile guiding the

column2: in which the encoder is constructed by multi-layer

propose a novel boundary energy loss (BEL) which introduces an energy

computer science#computing research repository#computer vision and pattern recognition#Recurrent Encoder-Decoder Networks for Vessel Trajectory Prediction with Uncertainty Estimation#Samuele Capobianco
column5: Peter Willett#"Recent deep learning methods for vessel trajectory prediction are able to

column1: learn complex maritime patterns from historical Automatic Identification System

applications
column2: reliably quantifying the prediction uncertainty can be as

column1: important as obtaining high accuracy. This paper extends deep learning

and aleatoric uncertainties. We compare the prediction performance of two

destination)."#10 pages

statistics#statistics#methodology#Choosing Exogeneity Assumptions in Potential Outcome Models#Matthew A. Masten
column2: Alexandre Poirier#"There are many kinds of exogeneity assumptions. How should researchers choose

column1: among them? When exogeneity is imposed on an unobservable like a potential
outcome
column2: we argue that the form of exogeneity should be chosen based on the

column1: kind of selection on unobservables it allows. Consequently

distributions of treatment given the unobservables that are consistent with

require a kind of non-monotonic relationship between treatment and the
potential outcomes. We discuss how to assess the plausibility of this kind of

identification. We apply these results in an empirical illustration of the
effect of child soldiering on wages."#"This paper supersedes our previous paper titled ""Interpreting Quantile Independence"" ()"
